millsfield:images_texts:
AMERICA'S
GREATEST
AIRPORT
AN FRANCISCO harbor was
once, scientists tell us, a
placid lake lying in a valley.
Then the earth
heaved and
the ocean crashed through
Golden Gate
making the
greatest natural harbor in the western
hemisphere.
Today this city
- a metropolis be-
cause of its magnificent harbor
-plans
to enlarge its airport to one that will
compare with the famous airfields of
Croyden,
Germany-
England, and
Tempelhof,
unapproached at present
by any in America.
Covering more
than 1,000 acres,
pierced by an arterial highway twenty
minutes from the city's center and
flanked on three sides by the Bay of
San Francisco, Mills Field presents an
ideal site.
"If Mills Field is not a good one,"
said Col. Lindbergh,
"we all should
quit flying."
And his unqualified ad
miration has been confirmed by Gen-
eral Gilmore, Col. Brant, Commander
Kingsford-Smith and other
flyers of a national and in
ternational fame.
With but a fraction of
its field completed San
Francisco's Municipal Air-
port already enjoys the
distinction of staging the
largest army maneuvers
outside of a government
station and when com-
pleted
more than 2,000
airplanes, amphibians and
seaplanes can be parked
there.
OF SAN
FRANCISCO
BOULE-VARD
20 MINUTES
San Francisco's
Civic Center
SAN FRANCISCO
MUNICIPAL
AIRPORT
Proposed Plan for Additions
and Improvements to
MILLS FIELD

Mills
Field
SAN FRANCISCO
MUNICIPAL AIRPORT
0 BE America's first two-unit operated
airport, simplifying traffic rules and allowing
for the landing and take off of 2,000 planes.
Covers more than 1,100 acres.
Includes 500 acres restricted area for airplane
industries.
No flying hazards: free from congested area;
San Francisco Bay on three sides allowing
for yacht harbor.
nty minutes from city's center on arterial
highway.
Passed by all north and south bus routes.
Adjacent to Southern Pacific and Western
Pacific Railroads.
Ideal water landings for amphibians and sea-
planes.
Ideal year round climatical and visibility con-
ditions allowing entry and exit practically
every day in the year.
Good buoyancy and lift practically assured
at all times by prevailing northwest trade
winds.
Cost of proposed improvements $4,000,000.
THE PLANNERS OF
AMERICA'S GREATEST
AIRPORT
HON. E. J. SPAULDING
HON. CARL W. MILES
HON JEFERSON E PEYSER
CAPT. ROY N. FRANCIS
Already with
America's
SAN
FRANCISCO
Now Plans
The world's
greatest
AIRPORT
MILLS FIELD
Covering more than
1100 ACRES
on Bayshore Boulevard

properties.sfomuseum:description: Promotional brochure issued by Mills Field Municipal Airport of San Francisco; tri-fold fromat; white cover with text “Already with America's greatest sea port... San Francisco now plans the world’s greatest airport... Mills Field covering more than 1100 acres on Bayshore Boulevard”; contains schematic drawing and description of proposed airfield; back cover features images of Mills Field  planners E. J. Spaulding, Carl W. Miles, Jefferson E. Peyser, and Roy N. Francis.
